header.title: 'Political correctness going too far': Pioneer walk-on girl hits back at darts ban
header.subtitle: ONE of Britain’s first ever darts walk-on girls yesterday hit out at the “politically correct” decision to ban them. Karen Jean Cookson, 46, was one of the first to accompany players on to the stage at a TV darts tournament.
header.postText: 'The model from Blackpool now runs the Angels Elite agency, managing darts walk-on girls Daniella Allfree and Charlotte Wood.', 'Yesterday she revealed her devastation at their ban by the Professional Darts Corporation and Formula One’s decision to end the use of grid girls.', 'She said: I was one of the first darts walk-on girls when it was trialled in the 1990s at Blackpool’s Winter Gardens.', 'It was to create a more glamorous occasion and the atmosphere was amazing.', 'I chose to do it and today’s girls also choose to do it – but now their livelihoods are being taken away.', 'Many have children and it’s their career. Where’s it going to stop? This is political correctness going too far.', 'Karen, Sue Knight and Samanaha Hearn were the first TV darts walk-on girls in 1994. Karen stressed that glamour is part of the entertainment business.', 'She added: Every girl who has done it has absolutely loved it. They are not intimidated, they are respected and choose what they want to wear.', 'This is taking a woman’s choice away from her. We don’t interfere with anyone else’s job, so why are they interfering in ours?', 'Hottest walk on girls at the darts', 'After the darts ban was announced this week, Jade Slusarczyk, 32, a walk-on girl for seven years, said: Some people say having walk-on girls is demeaning or degrading but I do not feel degraded at all. I don’t wear skimpy outfits, I wear classy, knee-length dresses.', 'I have never been made to feel uncomfortable and there’s never been anything untoward. It’s like a big sporting family.', 'The Professional Darts Corporation said: “We regularly review all aspects of our events. This move has been made following feedback from our host broadcasters.', 'Meanwhile several grid girls have criticised Formula One’s decision to also abolish their role in the sport.', 'Model Rebecca Cooper tweeted: “Ridiculous that women who say they are ‘fighting for women’s rights’ are saying what others should and shouldn’t do.', 'Stopping us from doing a job we love.Political correctness gone mad.', 'Sean Bratches, F1’ s American commercial chief, said: Over the last year we have looked at a number of areas we felt needed updating', 'The practice of employing grid girls has been a staple of Formula One Grand Prix for decades. But we feel this custom does not resonate with our brand values.', 'Three-time world champion Sir Jackie Stewart, 78, admitted: These are different times we are living in.'
header.socioLingVar: Gender - General,Age - Youngsters,Social Class - Working class,Age - Over 65s,Age - General,Nationality - European or anti-Europeans

replies.commentText: Utter rubbish. Feminist organisations fight against FGM, child abuse and inequality all over the world regardless of 'a certain religion'. Have you never heard of Sisters in Is lam for example? Most of the women I know would describe themselves as 'feminist' and they were as appalled by the child abuse in Rotherham as they would have beeen wherever it had happened. You and a few others are clearly just trying to steer the discussion towards your own little agenda.Just accept that most people no longer want to see women being objectified. 'A certain religion' has nothing to do with it.

What deafening silence? I suggest you look at organisations like the Feminist Majority Foundation, The Association for Women's Rights in Development or the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom and stop making glib assumptions to suit your own 'argument'.
Don' just tell us about these organisations. Elucidate their protests for us. Tell us actually what they said - nothing much I would guess because they don't want to cause offence.

They all campaign against FGM and they all campaign in favour of human rights and equality for women and lesbians.  There are quite a few regular contributors on here who don 't think women should be treated equally, so perhaps you should have a go at them instead of inventing what feminists do or don' t say just so you can have a pop at them.

There were no specific complaints by them against the Rotherham scandal as far as I know, because that would be criticising a certain culture. Indeed, complaints about this on social media recently have drawn the attention of the police for constituting a hate crime. You must not offend the sensibilities of our 'enrichers', it seems. You couldn't make it up - as they say nowadays.

commentThread.commentText: If they are banning this, then it's time to ban Miss Universe, Miss World, those silly pageants that display little girls like s.exy dolls. How are those better than some walk on girls? Oh, puhleeeze. Let these young women have their moment of glamour. I think they should add some walk on lads.

Beauty is not just a social construct as some would have us believe. Our eyes and brains pretty consistently like some human forms better than others. Shown photos of strangers, even babies look longer at the faces adults rank the best-looking. For similar reasons, many still thrill to the centuries-old bust of Nefertiti, the Venus de Milo, and the exquisite faces painted by Leonardo and Botticelli. Greta Garbo’s acting style seems stilted today, but her face transcends time. We know beauty when we see it, and our reactions are proven as remarkably consistent. So,we must be careful to understand that seeing beauty is not just a social construct to be changed but also a natural one .....and given that we can appreciate beauty simply for beauties sake as illustrated above ... I say let them continue. I feel aggrieved that other people can so easily destroy our own appreciation of beauty to fit some sordid or warped political agenda. They can use the remote control to turn it off.... nobody forces them to watch and let the rest of us appreciate what our brains tell us we should appreciate. Thank you for reading my tuppence worth.

There is no answer to this one really. On the one hand we have we have movie stars, models, music artists, celebrities and glamour girls flaunting the raunchiest, sexually explicit outfits at every opportunity by choice. It is their livelihood and often brings in gazillions of dollars. On the other, many of the same women are now objecting to women being sexualised and viewed as objects based solely on their physical attributes. I have often found the treatment of women based on how young, beautiful and scantily clad they are degrading and sometimes quite offensive. The worrying thing is the target age for much of this media hype is getting younger. For young girls it is especially difficult and not surprising now they have problems with self esteem, self harming, eating disorders and so on. But, women are perpetuating this themselves and are doing it by choice of career which you can't argue with. But, it seems that it is impossible to have it both ways!

replies.commentText: I agree, it is a complex issue with multiple conflicting arguments. My point of view is that 'Grid-girls' and 'walk-on girls' seem anachronistic in this day and age. Presumably they choose to go into the job and do not feel demeaned by it, though of course we don't all have choices in what we do in life. However it seems to me that to have your purpose simply to be standing looking pretty while holding a banner or a trophy or whatever, reduces that woman to one single aspect of her humanity - her prettiness, thus objectifying her. This is literally de-grading her, and by extension, all women. Condoning this communicates that we as a society accept that this is a reasonable way to view a woman. Film stars and musicians do at least present multiple facets of their humanity and are fulfilling roles other than simply looking pretty, so perhaps in this way they are different. I think that societies make small incremental steps towards being more progressive, and it feels to me that at this point in time, most of our society no longer accepts the idea of a woman 's sole purpose in a job being to look pretty/glamorous. I have two daughters, one a 14 y ear old who finds it incomprehensible that ' grid - girl ' is even, as she says "a thing". I am pleased that she took it for granted that women would be valued for more than their appearance.
